reviewText: One on one competition at it's finest. No teams to fall back on or get in the way. No killstreaks. No map advantage. No gear. No excuses. Super Street Fighter IV is the finest current game that the fighting game genre has to offer. With remarkably deep mechanics, great balance, and a seemingly limitless skill cieling, it's obvious why that after 4+ years, the latest iteration of Street Fighter 4 is still the most played fighting game out there these days. Button mashers beware, you'll get nowhere online against the people that play this game. You'll get your ♥♥♥ kicked relentlessly until you learn to kick back, but earning that clutch victory against a skilled opponent is one of the most satisfying feelings in all of multiplayer gaming. For those that want a truly competitive experience, I really can't reccommend any game as highly as this. That is, as long as you're ready to rise to the challenge. It will be a very long and brutal road to becoming a good player in a game like this.

reviewText:
Remember all the great fun you had playing Karate, Swordfight at Midnight, Fighting Road, and Super Black Belt Karate???  Of course you don't.  Why??  Because they all sucked a mile of chicken butt.  There's actually a long list of fighting games that have been put out to the masses over the years but only a choice few actually stand out amongst all the others as great and memorable fighting games.  Ultra Street Fighter IV along with the majority of the Street Fighter franchise is one of those few.  Pop quiz time...... Name all the current Ultra Street Fighter IV characters that also appeared in the original 1987 release of Street Fighter.  I'll give you the answer at the end.

If you've never played a Street Fighter games now is a great time to try your hand at it.  Controls are smooth and easy to grasp with a little work.  Gameplay is realitively easy to grasp but difficult to master, which in my opinion is a mark of a great game.  Online play seems to be smooth and there's plenty to do solo too as no two fights, online or off, will ever be the same.  With all the different characters in USFIV there's bound to be at least one character you side with,  As a matter of fact, there's so many different characters that if there was a downside it's that it's hard to settle in on  just one fighter if you'r new.

If you have played Street Fighter games before then what are you waiting for?  There's a fairly good chance at least one of your favorite characters from a previous version is just waiting for you to use them in a fight.  All your old memorized combos, supers, are still here and most likely use the same movements and button combos to execute.  And if you're looking for something new there's plenty of new and new/old characters too as well as some new moves and ultras.  This has certainly got to be one of the prettiest looking Street Fighters to date.  Colors pop, backgrounds look amazing and have loads of funny/interesting characters in them, and every character has several different DLC costumes you can buy if you so choose.  Other than the cosmetic character costumes though there's no game changing DLC within USFIV so yo don't need to worry about pay to win junk here.

Overall the game looks and plays amazing and is great fun.  Since you can also play two player on the same screen/PC it also makes a great party game and looks amazing on a nice big screen TV or monitor.  If there was one major downside it would be that the game doesn't play well with a keyboard/mouse or a standard Xbox controller.  You can do it sure, but you'll most likely be at a disadvantage when playing against someone who has invested in and trained on a fightpad, fightstick, or one of the newer hitbox controllers.  Owning one of those types of controllers though opens up a world of other interesting gaming on Steam though as all fighting games and many other arcade style games found on Steam just feel better when you use one with it.

So the answer to the question at the top:  Ryu, Ken, Gen, Adon, and Sagat.  There was also another character named Mike who greatly resembles the boxer Balrog so I guess he gets a half point...  Another character from the original Street Fighter named Eagle also appeared in Capcom vs SNK but not in USFIV.  There's your history lesson for today folks...

Really awesome game.

reviewText:
One of the best modern fighting games out there. Don't be ignorant about the online ranked match lag. It isnt the game's fault, it's steam's. Most of the time, it's pretty decent any way. Now to the actual game.

Pros:
-Deep gameplay you would expect from a Street Fighter title
-One of the best rosters the series has ever seen
-Very ballanced game, matchups dont get any worse than 3-7, and there aren't many 3-7's
-Simple enough for a beginner, complex enough for the fighting game gods

Cons:
-The sound quality of the in-game chat is really bad
-Community isnt very big (this game is played mostly by console players)

Misc. Comments:
-Best played on an arcade stick, but a standard game pad will suffice
-Players on steam aren't as good as the players on console (For example, I would consider a player with up to 500PP free" on console

reviewText:
Most of us could never forget those local arcades even if we wanted to. The smoke, the loud cheesy music, and the nasty Cheetos residue that seemed to be on every joystick.

Street Fighter 4 (in this case Ultra Street Fighter 4, not to be confused with the other 4 iterations) keeps this spirit alive in arguably the most classic fighting franchise in history, with fresh coats of paint and brand new systems. Being a 6 button fighter, I'd imagine you already own a PC compatible arcade stick or a different pad if you so prefer. Unless you want eternal carpal tunnel or feel the need to flex your masochistic man-boobs, avoid using the keyboard at all costs.

Most reviews will say DON'T EVER BUY THIS GAME EVER EVER CUZ LAAAGGG :((((" and they honestly have somewhat of a point. It's difficult to improve at such a difficult game without fighting others online - one of the most demanding online games to date that requires near perfect execution
date: which is damn near impossible in some of the servers you get set into during a ranked match. As long as you aren't playing on a toaster
recommended: this game will run perfectly fine for all other modes including 2 player local versus. But let's face it
hoursPlayed: at least 80% of your playtime will be in the training room against an auto-blocking Abel. Let's face it
voteText: he has the most consistent hitbox
helpfulPercent: or maybe you just hate the French.\n\nAll in all
votesHelpful: USF4 is that arcade experience we've always known and loved
votesTotal: but excluding those guys who don't shower and wear Etnies. What a bonus! Comes packed with great content and all them #alternateskinzzz. If Capcom can get their ♥♥♥♥ together with the netcode
votesFunny: there's absolutely no reason for a fighting game enthusiast to not pick this title up on the genetically superior platform."

reviewText:
The latest iteration of the Street Fighter franchise.
Since the transition to Steamworks, online play has been plagued by inconsistent network perfomance.
The latest update brought Omega mode, a selectable character mode in versus and endless games, bringing new moves and different properties to the whole cast. It was released to keep SFIV fresh while waiting for the next installment, Street Fighter 5.
Omega is hit and miss. Some characters completely changed compared to their vanilla" counterparts
date: other got some welkcome (or unwelcome) additions. It's all but balanced
recommended: but I don't think that was the main aim for this mode.\n\nBe aware though
hoursPlayed: for newcomers this game can be brutal. The largest part of the userbase are players with years of experience. It's a game with a pretty steep learning curve
voteText: as a newcomer

reviewText:
This is a very hard game to review under Steam's system of recommended versus not recommended. Even though I have it set to not recommended, I plan on continuing to play this game extensively. I also think it's a very well made game with extremely tight balance. Yes, even Dan is playable in this game (though still not great, by design).

If you're a fighting game enthusiast, then odds are you already own this game. If you don't, and you really are into fighting games, then get it. I fully recommend it, just be aware that this game is much slower paced than most 2d fighters. Combos tend to be short and difficult to execute, as opposed to being long and fairly easy. Other than that, there's nothing here that should be out of the ordinary to you.

For everyone else... this is not a game you can simply pick up and begin playing. The single player content is as bare bones as could be, providing a training mode, a short arcade mode, and then a series of trials for every character. I'll get to the trials in a moment.

Quite simply, this game does not teach you anything. It does not delicately introduce you to its mechanics and help you learn. If you want to play this game, you must dedicate yourself to it or else you're basically throwing your money away. I've played a lot of fighting games, especially in the Soul Calibur, Smash and Marvel vs Capcom series, and this game is the single most prohibitavely difficult game to begin playing of any of them. The trials I mentioned, while they do help you learn some things about your chosen character, there's nothing in the game that teaches you about the core fundamentals of how to play it.

At this point, I've spent more time practicing, studying (using online research, as again there's not much here that will teach you on its own) and learning this game than any other I've ever played. That includes things traditionally considered hard to learn, such as MOBAs like Dota 2. In fact I'd probably guess I've spent as much time with this game trying to learn it as I spent with the majority of the college classes I took when I was still in school. I am not exaggerating in the slightest. And after all that, I still lose the vast majority of the time, despite the fact I have fairly good win percentages in other fighting games. Or at the least, not as crushingly awful as my current 15ish to 120ish win:loss ratio.

You're also probably going to want to buy a specialized controller for it, like a Madkatz Fightpad or an arcade stick (and good arcade sticks cost as much as some tablets, keep in mind). You can play it with a keyboard or a regular controller, and there are a small number of really good keyboard warriors, but I think it's generally accepted that these methods are harder than playing with a stick or a specialized fightpad controller.

And that's really why I have to set this game as not recommended, despite the fact I love it. It's entirely unacceptable that I am currently almost 70 hours played after doing online research since the game does almost nothing to teach you anything itself, and I still barely understand what's going on. At this point I'm just continuing to play it because I'm just starting to reach the point where I don't feel completely lost and overwhelmed, but the satisfaction I get out of it is about the same as if I had just booted up my Wii U and played Smash Brothers instead, a game which is far more accessable.

If you have a true commitment to learning this game, and you don't mind getting utterly crushed for an extensive amount of time and buying extra peripherals just to play it, then go ahead and get it. Also, pick Guile or Ryu for the first little while, as those characters are made to help new players learn the game while still being powerful at high skill levels. Pick Ryu if you like quarter circle characters, or Guile if you like charge characters... and if you don't know what a charge character is, look it up, because the game won't tell you. For everyone else, save your money and look elsewhere. You will just get frustrated and feel like you wasted your time.

reviewText:
***This review is intended for people who are newer or unfamiliar with fighters. If you're an experienced fighting game player you probably already know why you love or hate this game!***

This is the gold standard for fighting games. No fighter out there is more balanced, rewards fundamentals and guesses/reads more intelligently, or has the staying power of USF4.

The balance is so impressive. So often, fighting games eventually mature to the point where people have found the 2-3 most powerful characters and the rest of the cast is ignored. In USF4 there are definitely characters considered better than others, but the top tier" consists of almost a dozen characters
date: and every single character of the 40+ in the game
recommended: even the "low tier" is extremely viable.\n\nThis game will force you to play more solidly than a lot of other fighters. Button mashers beware - you may take a few rounds now and then but this game is designed to punish you HARD. In fact
voteText: THIS GAME AND EVERYONE WHO PLAYS IT WILL KICK YOUR ♥♥♥. It will stay that way for probably at least 100 hours in. And even then
helpfulPercent: the skill ceiling is practically infinite. When I bought Street Fighter 4: AE I knew nothing about fighting games. 1400 hours later I'm finally at a level where I'd consder myself "decent". On the way
votesHelpful: I've discovered everything about what makes fighters an intelligent
votesTotal: deep
votesFunny: addicting
commentsCount: and all around amazing genre
column16: way beyond what I had ever imagined. It's a genre that can make you feel the raw sting of defeat (where unlike in MOBAs
column17: you only have yourself to blame) and the consequent high of a hard-won victory.\n\nThere is a definite lack of in-game resources for learning
column18: so you'll start off stuck in a trench of sorts. You'll have to spend a long time reading up online and practicing to get acclamated to the game systems
column19: which to some may seem archaic at times (1 frame links are a common source of frustration). But if you can fight through this and make it out of this phase you'll be on a journey to discover what makes fighting games truly amazing."

It's entirely unacceptable that I am currently almost 70 hours played after doing online research since the game does almost nothing to teach you anything itself, and I still barely understand what's going on. At this point I'm just continuing to play it because I'm just starting to reach the point where I don't feel completely lost and overwhelmed, but the satisfaction I get out of it is about the same as if I had just booted up my Wii U and played Smash Brothers instead, a game which is far more accessable.

If you have a true commitment to learning this game, and you don't mind getting utterly crushed for an extensive amount of time and buying extra peripherals just to play it, then go ahead and get it. Also, pick Guile or Ryu for the first little while, as those characters are made to help new players learn the game while still being powerful at high skill levels. Pick Ryu if you like quarter circle characters, or Guile if you like charge characters... and if you don't know what a charge character is, look it up, because the game won't tell you. For everyone else, save your money and look elsewhere. You will just get frustrated and feel like you wasted your time.

reviewText:
PC Netcode aside,

Street Fighter IV is one of the best entry-level games if you're looking to get into fighters. It will teach you the essentials of footsies, patience, and pattern recognition, while all-in-all providing you with solid and (for the most part) balanced competitive gameplay one would expect in a fighter.

Though it may be beginner friendly, don't go in with the expectation of immediately winning every match. Learning this game will be a slow, but satisfying experience in the end.

(If you're playing on a wifi connection, don't bother with hosting games. Wired connections are really the only way to go if you're looking for a smooth online experience.)

reviewText:
Street fighter 4 is largely regarded as being the current centrepiece of the fighter genre, this is perhaps due to the fact that it is essentially an updated and carefully expanded version of Street Fighter 2 – the game that in many respects defined the genre.

The motions and inputs required to perform moves are often daunting to players unfamiliar with fighting games and accustomed to the streamlined, immersive control schemes of today's FPS games and platformers, where pressing the 'right buttons' isn't really a factor you have to worry about. This may be in part the reason why Street fighter has a smaller (but no less passionate) following than the big MOBA, RTS and FPS games despite being such a rich and strategic game. Because to access that part of the game where you need to consider timing, reading, predicting, matchups etc you must first be able to pull off the moves and subsequent combos reliably, a process that can be a barrier to new players.

But at the same time this is what makes Street fighter so great. The controller motions and inputs and the special attacks they yield have a sense of logic to them. 'Shoto' characters launch most of their special moves by timing an attack at the end of a quarter circle movement with the joystick. 'Charge' characters achieve their special moves by momentarily holding the joystick in one direction and then pressing an attack as they move it in the opposite. Grappling characters launch devastating throws and slams by doing entire loops with the joystick just before they attack, and Special and Ultra moves are done by pulling off really quick 'double movements' and by pressing down three buttons at once. The inputs for moves don't feel like arbitrary sequences or codes but rather appropriate movements. This sort of gameplay, which has it's roots in the video game Arcade, has a genuinely tactile quality to it that lends itself to representing fighting and martial arts.

On top of that Street Fighter boasts some of the most iconic video game characters of all time who are conceptually inseparable from their signature special moves. In summary, Street Fighter is to many, including myself, the definitive 2D fighting game franchise and Street fighter 4 ULTRA with it's insane roster of 44 distinct playable characters is the best version to date.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I'm awful at this game, thus I spend a lot of time angry at it.

But I think the reason I dislike it is some ratio of that, the fact that the game just feels clunky, stiff and robotic, and that the AI cheats. Hard to pinpoint what ratio that really is.

The presentation is alright. The 3D models animate pretty well and all, but eh, 2D was better and had much more personality. I wish everybody didn't yell so many quips in mid-combat. Voice acting mainly ranges from unremarkable to bad, with a few exceptions. Music is decent across the board and actually sometimes pretty excellent.

Upgrading from Super to Ultra earns you five new (read: mostly rehashed from SFxTK) characters and a handful of new (read: mostly rehashed from SFxTK) stages. Also probably some rebalancing or whatever that most players will never notice. I gotta admit I really like Rolento though. And I do appreciate the sheer volume of characters.

I...ugh. This game just went so far backwards from SF3 and SFA3. Seems like every action in the game imposes a quarter-second or more delay on anything else you do. I mean I don't -hate- it, but gameplay never seems satisfying to me, always leaves me feeling like I just spent an hour arguing with something. I'd be willing to overlook most everything else except that the AI uses that patented read your button inputs and always respond with the one perfect thing you are mathematically not prepared for" style which is pretty much one of my least favorite things on earth. That ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t becomes a matter of outsmarting/tricking a computer instead of playing the game. Yes
recommended: play with humans instead. If you've got friends to play with
voteText: but I don't have the mental fortitude these days to put up with randoms.\n\nI guess I'll refrain from plugging a specific other franchise this time

votesFunny: that's for sure. Like SF2 but slower and clumsier. I don't want to call it bad

reviewText:
This game is a joke! It's not possible to effectively play it with a keyboard and it does not recognize a gamepad. In order to play it with a gamepad it requires to switch windows with Alt+Tab and then switch back to the game again. While playing with a keyboard, some characters are not moving back and forth, and it's almost impossible to perform special moves. Besides, special moves do not cause substantial damage. Taking into account the time you need to spend on pressing special combination, it's better to just stick with the combos. The story and character lines are too cheesy even for a fighting game. The gameplay itself is boring. I feel really disappointed with this game, although it was one my favourite titles back in the days of 8-bit consoles.

Full price, costs of upgrade, DLCs and costumes are a steal. Capcom is just exploiting the popularity of the title.

My only comfort is that I bought USFIV with 75% discount. It's still not worth it.

Overall rating: 4/10.

If you want a decent fighting game, go get Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition" or "Injustice: Gods Among Us" during sales time. It has much more to offer for a lower price. Or

you still risk failure.

make online play is exceedingly difficult.

- The level of competition in this game is too high. My win percentage

column23: Steam didn't record hours played in offline mode.) I've spent nearly as much time researching in an effort to get better. Nothing has worked-out. Ultimately
column24:
I gave up on being good. Improving in the game feels more like work than entertainment.

- The sad part is that I'm actually pretty good at the game. It just doesn't matter because my average opponent is still x10 better. I've wasted a lot of time on this game. Don't make the same mistake! Abandon all hope if you play USF4 online.

5) Online PLAYERS
- The vast majority of people you'll run into online are jerks. There is a lot of trash talk. There is a lot of rage. (Not surprising really.) It is so bad
column25: I had to mute voice chat. The better players will stomp you
column26: and then play around. They won't even fight you. They'll just run away as long as they have the advantage. If you try to give up
column27: most players won't accept it. They'll hit you a few times
column28: and then taunt until time runs out. Alternately
column29: they send a trollish message like
column30: "whats wrong ;D".\n\n- The kind of person that plays this game... you don't want to know that kind of person. Here's a quote from "The Fighting Game Primer" which can be found at the popular shoryuken website: "Your job is to take the tools the designers have given you - characters with moves - and turn the game into a sheer mess of broken parts that no one ever wants to play again." This ideal has been widely adopted by online players. It is a very good reason to avoid this game. Being locked into place
column31: unable to move because your opponent's attacks never end? That's not fun.\n\n- The Fighting Game Community(FGC) are made up of the most elitist people you will ever encounter. They like to say
column32: "nothing is cheap". Yet these same people complain when someone is "random" or "lame" or "spammy". Their gameplay is highly respectable
column33:
yours is lame. See?

6) Arcade Mode
- The best part of this mode is the arcade experience. By that
column34: I refer to the "Battle Request" feature. This allows online players to challenge you whilst you play Arcade Mode. (Just like at a real arcade!) Aside from that
column35: it's bad news. Even on "medium" CPU opponents can be unbelievably difficult. (Blocking everything and countering/punishing with ultra/super!)\n\n- A.I. has improved considerably in Ultra. It now fights much like a typical online warrior. Which means it will cheese you to death. It will find a move you have trouble dealing with
column36: and it will spam it. If you have trouble teching throws
column37: it'll throw you at every opportunity. If there's a specific special move that keeps hitting you
column38: it'll use that move frequently. This is both good AND bad. For one thing
column39: it's really annoying. (It's nice to just fight a dumb A.I. sometimes.) On the other hand
column40: it better prepares players for online play. Anything that can do *that*
column41: is a BIG plus. The A.I. will also block/avoid/punish a lot of things that previously
column42:
it would ignore. (Like Ultras. Instead of just eating them. Although it still does that occassionally.)

- Seth still too strong. It must be hard to balance a character with all the greatest moves the game has to offer! Still... more than a little ridiculous that everything he does is un-punishable.

7) Ultra Combos
- Ultra combos are like super moves
column43: only more potent. Ultras are represented by a meter separate from your super meter. The ultra meter is charged as you take damage. The idea is that this gives you a big attack with which to make a comeback. Unfortunately
column44: most characters make it VERY obvious that they are going to utilize their Ultra. As a result
column45: most Ultras are very easy to block or evade entirely. Even worse
column46: your character will just stand there helplessly for several seconds afterward. So
column47: performing your Ultra could lose you the match.\n\n- It is possible to make your Ultra part of a bigger combo. However
column48:
this almost always requires a difficult timing that demands precise execution. (Which can be ruined by marginal lag.) It's just another tool for the good players to beat you. So much for a comeback!

8) Old-School Experts
- Many of Street Fighter's biggest fans (and pros) have joined Capcom over the years. As a result
column50: for pros." If EVO is any indication
column51: they like SF just the way it is. Many pros acknowledge the game is quite difficult to get into
column52: but they have no idea. If you developed your skills back during the days of S-Turbo
column53: then you don't know what it is like to start these days. A lot of what you have learned has become something you just assume
column54: or take for granted. I'm being asked to learn
column55: before I can EVER hope to win
column56: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS worth of tactics and strategies.\n\nI gave up on this one. I only play to remind myself why I quit! I can't recommend it to anyone. Even if you have LOADS of free time to sink into the game. After two years of effort
column57: I'm ready to say it's just not possible to get into this genre. You have to have natural talent. You simply CANNOT train to be good at this game.\n\nDon't believe me? Have fun losing. Because
column58: if you are not god-like-perfect at fighting games
column59: losing is the only possibility when you play Street Fighter IV online. If you hear that this game is great for casual play
column60: please know this is a lie. This is not a game for casual or even average players. This game is for fighting game PROS ONLY. Anyone else will waste their money and time. (Like me.)"

reviewText:
Ultra Street Fighter IV is the latest and (probably) last addition to the Street Fighter IV series. It features 5 new characters, new stages, new soundtrack and tons of balance changes to the roster.

A word of advice to beginner fighters: Don't buy this game unless you have an arcade stick (fighting stick) or a good gamepad. The keyboard is not meant for fighting games, even if some people CAN make it work. Being good and enjoying a fighting game takes a lot of commitment. Hundreds of hours in minimum and thousands of hours realistically speaking.

+Great gameplay. A good entry-level fighter for beginners too.
+A huge roster of varied characters.
+Good soundtrack with many iconic songs from the past.
+Active community.
+Smooth 60 FPS animation and beautiful visuals.

-Mediocre netcode. Online multiplayer is still prone to lagging and connection time-outs. This is has been patched somewhat successfully and will be further patched in the future.
-Could use a proper tutorial à la Skullgirls. There are character trials and a manual, but no real tutorial.

reviewText:
The 5th iteration of Street Fighter 4 on PC, and somehow the game has taken gigantic steps backwards.

The game itself, not just the netcode, still needs a major patch and at this point, I don't think we'll ever get it. For example, sometimes the MENUS lag. Yeah.

Widespread frame rate and other assorted graphical issues for almost all users from the get-go, with no clear, definitive way to fix them. There are so many guides and posts for tweaks and workarounds that users can utilize on their end to make the game playable, but there are also so many issues that it becomes pretty confusing. Some fixes work for some users and have no effect for others.

Whatever the Steam transition and the release of Ultra did to this game really broke it. The netcode is infamously terrible and has been covered to death. It has improved but still bad overall.

Do I recommend this game? Yes and no.
Yes, if you are willing to tinker with the game and your system to get it running right. USF4 can be a lot of fun. With that said, there are issues you WILL need to address if you decide to play, and there are still many issues with the online play. So keep those things in mind before you buy.

I don't know if Capcom will get this game fixed. Despite the beta and patch, many problems remain.

reviewText:
This game is good, but it comes with a few conditions:

If you have shaky internet, don't expect a good online experience.  It won't even come close to acceptable.

Use forced Vsync via your graphics card (NOT IN-GAME VSYNC).  For whatever crazy and nonsensical reason, this game runs better online with it slammed at 60 fps via Vsync and not just because you have the in-game option set to fixed".  Also
date: you'll want to mess around with your Vsync options to test for input lag.  For me
recommended: I use adaptive Vsync because the game is generally good at staying at a constant framerate on my setup
hoursPlayed: so this produces the best in both online environments and in terms of input lag for me.  Regular Vsync and triple buffered Vsync cause a noticable delay on my rig.  For others it is different and it really just depends
voteText: but using Vsync in some manner should be aimed for.\n\nThe game is standard SFIV fair: easy to understand
helpfulPercent: hard to master.  This game is both deceptively accessible and not accessible.  Be warned

reviewText: As far as fighters go this is the cornerstone. I feel that no fighter collection would be complete without this one. In my personal opinion I'm not the biggest fan of fighters but this one catches my attention. I've always kinda sucked at fighters but this one was easy to learn because of its great range in characters. Some characters are very simple for beginners and get gradually more complicated as you rise in skill level. That being said there are very few to no characters that i would say are op" or "cheap" and none of which are unbeatable given your own skill level when facing them. The networking isn't the best as we all know
date: but I can't say that it's been horrid for me when playing with people in my area or others that share the same connection. I've used almost any controller you can think of from consoles to fight sticks and havent had any issues. Taking everything into account
recommended: I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants to get into fighters."

reviewText: an excellent game to introduce you to the genre, although the absolute best in-game tutorial for fighting games would be in skullgirls. this game does not have an in-game tutorial and many concepts are left for you to figure out on your own. i can't think of anything in the current state of the game that a casual player would immediately be able to identify as cheap or spammable. you must exercise fundamentals to get anywhere in this game and those skills (zoning, footsies, neutral, decision making, positioning, match-up recognition, frame data) can easily translate to other games in the genre, or all games if you're a huge nerd like me! i highly recommend learning the game with a buddy since the online player base is highly experienced and, even though you can learn from losses, you will get much more from playing with someone on a similar skill level. shoryuken.com , youtube tutorials, and watching streams of the game on twitch.tv are good ways to learn, but nothing beats playing a friend.\n\nsettings wise, it is a MUST that you turn OFF vsync (having it on will introduce input lag, although i heard it is not bad if you implement it on a driver level) and set frame rate to FIXED (allows the game to always run the game at 60fps, even if that means skipping frames [essential for gameplay since it keeps timings consistent and is as the game was intended to be played]. setting this to variable or smooth will allow the game to run under 60fps and this is bad due to multiple gameplay and netcode reasons.)

reviewText: Most balanced fighting game there is. If you care about tier lists you would see that tiers are pretty close to each other. Of course top tier has a small advantage but tiers shouldn't matter to people that have less than 1000 hours of playtime. There's no god tier like in some fighters. Replayability is off the roof with this franchise.\n\nUltra Street Fighter 4 has the biggest online fighting game community so if you want to have lots of online matches I recommend this. Some people have issues with online but it works well for me as long as you stick with endless. To be honest, netplay is better than in King of Fighter XIII Steam version when you get it to work.

reviewText:
I have spent so much time playing this game on the Xbox 360 that my PC time seems absolutely miniscule in comparison.

I must have played over 30000 matches at this point, which sounds absurd but that's a fraction of what people who are really serious about the game have played! Not to mention countless hours in training mode, completing all the trials, watching replays.

Street Fighter IV is easily my favourite competitive multiplayer game of all time and certainly near the top of my favourite games period.

reviewText:
This game is good, but it comes with a few conditions:

If you have shaky internet, don't expect a good online experience.  It won't even come close to acceptable.

Use forced Vsync via your graphics card (NOT IN-GAME VSYNC).  For whatever crazy and nonsensical reason, this game runs better online with it slammed at 60 fps via Vsync and not just because you have the in-game option set to fixed".  Also
date: you'll want to mess around with your Vsync options to test for input lag.  For me
recommended: I use adaptive Vsync because the game is generally good at staying at a constant framerate on my setup
hoursPlayed: so this produces the best in both online environments and in terms of input lag for me.  Regular Vsync and triple buffered Vsync cause a noticable delay on my rig.  For others it is different and it really just depends
voteText: but using Vsync in some manner should be aimed for.\n\nThe game is standard SFIV fair: easy to understand
helpfulPercent: hard to master.  This game is both deceptively accessible and not accessible.  Be warned
votesHelpful: you will have the urge to practice.  And if you don't
votesTotal: well time to move on I guess."

reviewText:
fighting in streets
streets in fighting
get grappled a bunch by Zangief, rage, repeat, until you find a way to screw him over

Typical enjoyable fighting game which, along with Skullgirls, serves as a great way for newbies to get into the fightain scene
Ultra is the definite version and if you already have the original, Ultra is worth the 15 dollars asking price for a good amount of upgrades, features, mechanics, characters, and balance changes.

If you're new to fighters, get Ultra and find a character you like, screw with his moves in training, get some buddies to fight, ask questions on Shoryuken, have fun
You will not regret this decision.

reviewText:
[Opening]
I'm going to have to revoke my previous review for this game because I just realized I've played every Street Fighter game 'cep' 1 and Alpha 1, including the Street Fighter V beta.  And, in hindsight, I've discovered just how terrible the controls are in this game.

I grew up in the arcades back in the day, playing Samurai Shodown, Street Fighter II Champion Edition, World Heroes and whatever else I could stick my quarters into.  I've always known fighting games to have tight controls, and while I haven't always played them competitively (as much as I would've loved to), this game does not have tight controls.  Lemme tell you what you can expect to see a lot of in this game.

[The Cons]
First off is negative edge.  Negative edge is present in all fighting games.  When you press a normal attack button, then cancel it into a special move, occasionally fighting games will take the previous button press and apply it to your next movement.  This usually happens if you take too long to release the first button you press in this sequence.  In Street Fighter IV, you can expect to see this happen a lot.

The next one is something I honestly don't know if there's a name for yet.  People who play this game will burn meter if for no other reason than to prevent the use of a super move.  They do this because sometimes, when you do a special move with a similar motion to your character's super move, the game will automatically cancel your previous special move into a super move, even if you only pushed the button once.

One frame links (and two frame links, etc.).  Just one frame links.  This is the only fighting game that has them.  For the uninitiated, a one frame link is when you press one normal attack button, then press another one at ONE VERY SPECIFIC frame of animation from the previous attack.  One frame at sixty frames a second.  Doing this is insanely difficult, ESPECIALLY ONLINE, and takes more patience and practice than anything I've ever had to do and I've been playing fighting games for over twenty years.  I just keep my combos simple.

The input leniancy.  This is the game's worst offender.  You will get misinputs for days on account of how the game guesses" when you do any complex motion.  It even lead to a glitch (or "feature") called priority linking
recommended: in which you press two buttons of the same type.  Say you want a medium kick to come out at the speed of a light kick.  What you do is press both buttons and the game will always give you the attack of the stronger button
hoursPlayed: but it gives it the priority of the lesser button pressed.  This makes combos easier
voteText: but this input leniancy applies to every button pressed.  When the game handles directional inputs...honestly
helpfulPercent: I don't know.  I haven't really figured out how it handles those at all.  There's been too many times I just don't know how I got the input I got.\n\nAnd before any of you scrubs who never played a Street Fighter game before come running to defend it saying "You just can't do these moves/combos 'cuz you suck
votesHelpful:
remember.  I've been playing fighting games for over 20 years.  I've put way more practice into Street Fighter as a franchise than any of you.  That being said, however, I'll list some pros, now that I've got all the cons out of the way.

[The Pros]
It's got a great cast of characters from all the Street Fighter games and some new ones.

It looks great.

The PC version has easily the best netcode.  You'll still get some lag (and laggers), but netcode doesn't fix people's bad connections, it just makes the game flow a little better.  And it does flow well.  When it wants to.

Being the most popular fighting game currently on the market, you'll never have trouble finding people to fight.  Online is always crowded, no matter which platform you play it on.  It saddens me that I can't blame the netcode for some of the BS that happens in this game.

Ranked mode's scoring and ranking is based off the same as professional chess tournaments.  You get points when you beat somebody, lose 'em when you lose and those points determine your rank.  PP (Player Points) applies to your rank as a player and BP (Battle Points) refers to your rank with your current character.

[Closing]
Play 3rd Strike on home consoles or wait for Street Fighter V.  If you haven't played this game yet, you're not missing anything.

reviewText: This game jettisons the high learning curve and time and skill investment that the various versions of SFIII required. SSF4:AE is something akin to SFII with a glossier coat and several new features, making for a well-balanced game that both novice and veteran fighters can pick up and enjoy with ease. Tons of neat characters, great music, and appealing visuals make this game one rock solid fighter. Unfortunately, the multiplayer aspect requires you to sign up for Games For Windows Live, which, had I known that, would have dissuaded me from buying it.

reviewText:
USF4 is currently the fighting game on Steam if you're at all interested in multiplayer. In terms of playerbase, the only real contender is MKX, but the online infrastructure on that is terrible and as such, most players playing it are actually playing the single player modes. Skullgirls' multiplayer has roughly 1/3 to 1/4 of Street Fighter's playerbase, and while it has an excellent tutorial mode and great netplay, it has the typical 'anime fighter' problem of having very fast gameplay and (generally) featuring more than two characters per match. This can get it in the way of learning; it's not always easy to identify what you're doing wrong or even what move the opponent did.

USF4 is a game with a steep, STEEP learning curve that is only exacerbated by its tight-knit community and the fact that the game is about seven years old. The majority of the players you'll come across online are hardened veterans and for a new guy like me, it can be maddening. I'm exceptionally proud of my ~15% win rate.

In my opinion it's the best option you have right now for learning fighting games. It's not too fast like Skullgirls can be, there's a community that's very receptive to newbies and will answer questions, and it's perfect preparation for the big fighting game boom pc gamers will get in 2016. Some time next year we'll get both Street Fighter V and Killer Instinct, and USF4 is your metaphorical gym membership to get ripped for those releases.

reviewText: My daughter and I have been on a fighting game kick lately.  I recently was diagnoised with MS and over the past few months gaming and life in general has gotten harder for me due to a number of issues, one of which is lose of motor control in my right hand.  I decide to help battle this by doing my own physical therapy via gaming.  Granted it is rather humbling that my 10 year old daughter is slaughtering me in fighting games, but none the less we are having fun.  Okay this is my lead in for this and a couple other fighting games I am reviewing tonight mostly to just set the some background.\n\nRight now there are three fighters we are playing Injustice, Skullgirls and Ultra Street Fighter IV.  Each of these three have their pros and cons.  Injustice has DC characters we enjoy.  Skullgirls has unique tag teams and artwork.  USFIV has a huge list of playable characters and is very well balanced.  My daughter thrashes me bad in the game.  Yes I am man enough to admit it.  That said we are still having a good time.  I picked up the game while on sale however and can't say that for the normal price that we would like it better than Injustice or Skullgirls.  Mainly because it is a complex game and the skill level is high.  I can't speak at all to online or against AI as I have only played against her.  All in all though we have enjoyed the game.  My daughter LOVES playing as Rose.  One question, OMG what is with the women and their huge thighs?  lol.

reviewText: My daughter and I have been on a fighting game kick lately.  I recently was diagnoised with MS and over the past few months gaming and life in general has gotten harder for me due to a number of issues, one of which is lose of motor control in my right hand.  I decide to help battle this by doing my own physical therapy via gaming.  Granted it is rather humbling that my 10 year old daughter is slaughtering me in fighting games, but none the less we are having fun.  Okay this is my lead in for this and a couple other fighting games I am reviewing tonight mostly to just set the some background.\n\nRight now there are three fighters we are playing Injustice, Skullgirls and Ultra Street Fighter IV.  Each of these three have their pros and cons.  Injustice has DC characters we enjoy.  Skullgirls has unique tag teams and artwork.  USFIV has a huge list of playable characters and is very well balanced.  My daughter thrashes me bad in the game.  Yes I am man enough to admit it.  That said we are still having a good time.  I picked up the game while on sale however and can't say that for the normal price that we would like it better than Injustice or Skullgirls.  Mainly because it is a complex game and the skill level is high.  I can't speak at all to online or against AI as I have only played against her.  All in all though we have enjoyed the game.  My daughter LOVES playing as Rose.  One question, OMG what is with the women and their huge thighs?  lol.

reviewText:
OH HELL YES I RECOMMEND THIS!

I've always been a sucker for Street Fighter games since Street Fighter 2 on super nintendo and it's my all-time absolute favourite game franchise alongside Serious Sam and Doom so keep that in mind while reading, I'll strive to be as objective as possible but it can include some bias.

I wasn't such a fan of the first SF4 which I had the occasion to play long time ago and was basically keeping going on Street Fighter 3 third strike (which is an awesome fighting game you gotta try!). But oh boy how things got better with this one!
The learning curve is top notch provided you have the patience to spend some hours on challenges and training room to find out some new tricks and combos. So far, the whole things looks extremely well-balanced and could never complain about a character being too cheap or overpowered (unlike that infamous vanilla-Seth who made me wonder if I was playing Street Fighter or some SNK stuff). The whole gameplay can look pretty SF2esque at first glance but in fact it includes many subtleties I'm discovering hour after hour with pleasure. It's one of those easy to handle
date: hard to master" games and even though I'm still basically losing online
recommended: the progress I did is extremely gratifying.\n\nOnline playing so far went good
hoursPlayed: I sure can't complain about the lag when defeated wich is a good thing. They included a replay mode which can record your matches if you wish and it's extremely useful to see where you sucked (no
voteText: don't tell me "it's boring to watch" DO IT. You can't imagine all the little flaws you can realize when the pressure went down.)\nDon't listen to guys on forums who speak about cheaters. I didn't spot any cheater here

reviewText:
SF4 is easily the best fighting game to come out in the past... I dunno, 10 years.  This is the game you basically need to play if you're into fighting games at all, imo.  It's a bit slower paced, yes.  But the roster is huge and varied, there's a character here for just about everyone's style.  The presentation can't be topped, I can't overemphasize how HYPE that ♥♥♥♥ gets.

SF4's neutral game is mostly about footsies and space control, in a really intense and understated way that not a lot of other fighting games can touch.  It's all about fundamentals, here.  You can learn your combos, sure.  You can spend time in training mode; absolutely, you should.  But the mindgames in SF4 are so crazy.  You don't have to be an input master to do well.

It also just so happens to be incredibly well balanced, especially considering how many characters there are.  It's got a pretty damn good online system, and you can watch other people's replays.  What more could you ask for?

As of the release of Ultra, there's quite a few new characters to screw around with, including some SF3 characters.  Most of them are pretty cool I guess?  None of them can replace my main, though.  NOW, FACE THE MIGHTY BISON.

date: then you probably haven't played SF4 ever and you're just an internet troll .The definitive version of the game. There really isn't any competition when it comes to deep
recommended: involved fighting mechanics. You aren't drowned in a quandary of different systems and minutia. Everything simply works.\n\nThe balance is also razor thin. The worst characters (when looking at a 10 point match up tier list) are only 20% below the best. The same can't be said for pretty much any fighting game aside from SF2. Using MVC3 as an example
hoursPlayed:
the best character is actually close to 250% better than the worst (on a match up based tier list).

You also don't have to sit there and watch the other person play while your character is endlessly juggled for half the match. Combos are there but they are swift and succinct. No more 15-20 second long combos of MVC3 and King of Fighters 13.

The character variety is amazing. The inputs are tight and responsive while also demanding that you learn your character. There is no dial-a-combo system

reviewText: Love this game, have played Street Fighter in arcades and at the local dairies and fish 'n' chip shops since I was a kid. SSFIV:AE is a very different game to those first few titles but it still evokes the same sense of awe when I play. Ultra SFIV is almost upon us and I am looking forward to the changes and the addition of a few new faces.\nWith all that said though, this game is BRUTAL to get in to as a beginner, even all the years I have played casually never really prepared me for the depth and technical possibilities of the SFIV series. That coupled with the absolutely average connections I get to most people (even in the same area, don't even mention overseas) can mean weeks of losses and probably the most frustration I have ever exprienced in a fighting game. But still, the payoff is there - you practice, you WILL get better. I almost liken this kind of game to the guitar, hours of practice is required to train your muscles to do the things in your head without actually thinking about the inputs. Actually, ♥♥♥♥ this game - it drives me nuts. Haha.

reviewText: Having played both SF IV (ps3) and USF IV (PC)  this update really delivers some much-needed upgrades to the original. There is a healthy variety of characters to suit playstyles and the movesets are the same as previous editions of the franchise. Definitely play this one with some kind of joystick instead of a Dpad or keys. Compared to when I played the original with a PS3 controller, the xbox is much more ergonomically sound. It's a solid game offline (haven't played online) and the combo timing is more forgiving  than other titles I've played in the genre. I'd say its major downside is that it feels old, because like most games that come from Capcom, this one doesn't rock the boat much. It's a great title for fans of the genre, but it probably won't win over any new faces. 7.5/10

reviewText:
(WORK IN PROGRESS)

Mechanics/Advanced techniques

FOCUS ATTACKS-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Focus attack: Pressing/Holding MP+MK will charge an attack that if connects will send the opponent into a crumpled state if certain conditions are met.

level 1 Focus: Pressing MP+MK won't make the opponent crumple unless it lands as a counter hit,

Level 2 Focus: Holding MP+MK until the character flashes white once and then letting go will execute a level 2 focus attack which if dash cancelled (FADC, see below) will always leave your character plus on frames and if it connects will cause the crumple state.

Level 3 Focus: Holding MP+MK until the focus attack executes by itself is a level 3 and is unblockable.

Red focus attack: Performed by holding down LP, MP, MK. Red focus attacks are a much more powerful version of the focus attack that instead of absorbing 1 hit with the use of hyper armour" absorbs an infinite amount of hits until the animation ends. A red focus can still be broken however much like a focus attack with the use of a special such as a shoryuken.

Advanced techniques-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

FADC: If you dash during the charging animation of the Focus attack it will cancel leaving your character ready to perform another action.

EXFADC: Certain special moves can be cancelled by using a focus attack to interrupt the animation then dashing which if executed correctly will make your character flash yellow
date:
and it will also consume 2 out of 4 pips of EX meter.

Properties and effects of focus attacks------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hyper Armour: During the charge up animation a focus attack can absorb 1 hit from an opponent. The 1 hit that can be absorbed from an opponent is aptly named Hyper armour
recommended: also known as Super armour. Hits that can be absorbed are specific and mostly limited to normal attacks such as LP

as well as most special moves that a character possesses.

White health: After absorbing an opponents attack a portion of your health will turn white. After a time your health will revert to its normal colour. If you get hit while the while health is regaining its colour you will lose the white health as well as take the damage of the attack landed.

reviewText:
As Street Fighter V inches ever so closer, I think it's time to take a look back on the lifespan of one of the more well-known entries in the series. Initally released in 2008, Street Fighter IV has seen so many subsequent updates and rereleases, some of which admittedly feel a bit unnecessary. Nonetheless, all of these versions have ensured the core game's place in the fighting game scene, It had its ups and downs, but Street Fighter IV is still a very robust and shining example of practically everything the series has to offer.
PROS
-Characters from all sorts of games (The original, II, Alpha, III, and a few new ones)
-The biggest roster of a Street Fighter game I know
-Several alternate costumes on top of that
-Easy-to-play, hard-to-master control scheme
-Version select (only available in local versus(sorry, Omega mode))
-Evil Ryu is waaaaaay better than regular Ryu

Of, course, it's not without its flaws:
CONS
-Character imbalance still sneaks through every once in a while
-Alternate costumes are paid DLC in spearate bundles organized by character archetytpes
-Arcade-Last-Boss Seth is still a cheating ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
-Lag can pose a greater threat than your opponent, depending on the connection
-Decapre (Would this be considered petty?)

Even with these flaws, Ultra Street Fighter IV is still the definitive version of the game(even if Seth Killian said that about Arcade Edition), and PC users can mod even more costumes in the game (can you say Spider-Man Fei-Long?). So, in short, I'd still recommend it. It could certainly make the time go by a little faster while waiting for Street Fighter V.

reviewText:
The best fighting game to date.
- Huge cast, including classic SF II chars like Guile and Bipson, new chars like Juri and Gouken, even Final Fight chars were added, like Cody and Poison.
- The core gameplay is still very similar to SF II, with a more slow game pace focused on zoning, anti-air and short combos.
- The new mechanics, like the focus attack and the ultras add more depth to the fight, make the game very technical on a high level.

The only problem I can think of is that some game mechanics like the focus cancel were made thinking in an arcade stick, you wont be able to pull it off on a pad or keyboard, so I would say that an arcade stick is recommend to play the game on a high level.

I rate it as: 5/5

reviewText:
What i DO like about the game:
* All Characters can be customized with different outfits and Taunts.
* Characters are relatively easy to learn.
* The Music is badass.
* Can hold it's own on just about any old Potato PC you own provided you play on all low settings.
* TONS More!!

What i DON'T like about the game:
* Certain Combo Moves like Specials and Ultras are fairly difficult to perform if playing on a Controller.
* Characters' Mouthes don't move in Sync with what they are saying. (This might be because the game was developed and published in Japan)
* Multiplayer Matchmaking tends to match you with Players ranked alot higher then you.

Overall Verdict:
86/100.

Recommended Playstyle:
Pro

Download Size:
14.81 GB
